Augustus and the Rowan Constitution
425
on this matter much that is of immense value,  and his whole study of the coinage lays the foundation for a much more minute analysis that was hitherto possible of the relations between Augustus and the provinces and cities of the empire It must remain unproven whether the legend CA on certain widely spread groups of ^^j' - coinage is to be interpreted »C ( AESARIS ) A ( UCTORITATE ) «,  but Grant's case for this view is extremely plausible " 7®.  Yet a doubt remains whether the title of his major work,  which reflects the main historical thesis of its author and insists on a firm and persistent contrast between imperium and auctoritas^ is not in some degree misleading.  This point will recur in the sections which follow below about Augustus' principal powers,  but two preliminary observations may be in place. 
i.  Atictoritas and potestas may be antithetic concepts,  but it is not unwise to remind ourselves at times of the obvious fact that they are not incompatible ^9.  We may then also remember the extent to which they are interdependent.  The origins of auctoritas are defined by Cicero treating of Pompeius in 66 B.  C. ,  and his language carries conviction.  If one may briefly paraphrase,  they were honores and res gestae \ and what above all brings auctoritas into being is the decision of the people in its capacity to confer on the man of its choice an office or command®®.  It is not surprising then to find in Cicero many instances where a man's auctoritas derives almost wholly from the office which he holds Obviously,  this was not always so.  Q.  Metellus Celer,  as consul - designate in 6i,  »id quod nondum potestate poterat,  optinuit auctoritate « ; and little support has been found for supposing that atictoritas derived exclusively from an »Amtswahl« or for the reasons which led Premerstein to suggest that in 27 B.  C.  the auctoritas of Augustus might have been conferred by law But in estimating the source of that particular auctoritas^ we must clearly reckon not only with the young Caesar's inheritance,  with his party,  with his position in Italy
77.  Important reviews of Grant's ¥rom Imperium to Auctoritas by C.  H.  V.  land appear in Class.  Rev. ,  1947,  114,  Journ.  R.  Stud. ,  1947,  209.  Criticism of the stitutional section may also be found in U Ant.  Class. ,  1946,  371 ( S.  J.  de Am.  Journ.  Phil. ,  1948,  317 ( M.  Hammond ). 
78.  From Imperium,  102 fF. 
79.  See Grant,  Constitution,  98,  quoted n.  54 above. 
80.  Cicero,  Imp.  Cn.  Pomp. ,  43,  »de quo homine vos,  id quod maxime facit auctori - tatem,  tanta et tam praeclara iudicia fecistis«. 
81.  de Leg.  Agr. ,  1.  24,  Rah.  perd. ,  22,  Mur. ,  82,  in Vat. ,  16,  ad Att. ,  I.  16.  2 all repay study : cf.  Velleius,  II.  126.  2,  »accessit magistratibus auctoritas«. 
82.  Cicero,  in Pis. ,  8,  a passage on which Schönbauer's discussion is most helpful. 
83.  Vom Werden,  ijGff.  ; Schönbauer,  65—75,  refutes this,  though how his own definition of auctoritas,  »politisch - rechtliche Macht oder Kraft im staatlichen Leben des Römerreiches«,  is an improvement on the now classic account of R.  Heinze ( Hermes,  1925,  348ff.  ),  I have been unable to discover.
